This to the method used in 'List of Lights' publications. A generic term such as 'to shore' cannot be used; a specific bearing must be encoded. Where a light sector limit is defined as 'to the shore', it should be encoded using a value that ensures that, when the limit is drawn, it will fall entirely on land.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Signal frequency
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The frequency of a signal.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Signal generation
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The mechanism used to generate a fog signal.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: automatically
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: signal generation is initiated by a self regulating mechanism such as a timer or light sensor.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: by wave action
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the signal is generated by the motion of the sea surface such as a bell in a buoy.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: by hand
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the signal is generated by a manually operated mechanism such as a hand cranked siren.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: by wind
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the signal is generated by the motion of air such as a wind driven whistle.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Signal group
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The number of signals, the combination of signals or the morse character(s) within one period of full sequence.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Signal output
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: Strength of signal output

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Signal period
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The time occupied by an entire cycle of intervals of light and eclipse.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Signal sequence
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The sequence of times occupied by intervals of light and eclipse for all 'light characteristics' except for occulting where the sequence of times is occupied by intervals of eclipse and light.
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: The 'signal sequence' for all 'light characteristics' except for occulting is indicated using a fixed format to encode the value of intervals of light (L) and eclipse (E).

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Sounding uncertainty
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The best estimate of the accuracy of the sounding data. The maximum of the one-dimensional error. The error is assumed to be positive and negative. The plus/minus character shall not be encoded.
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: The unit of measure is defined in the DUNI subfield of the DSPM record or in the DUNITS attribute of the M_UNIT meta object class, e.g., metre (m). The resolution is 0.1 m or 0.1 fm or 0.1 ft.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Source date
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The production date of the source, e.g., the date of measurement.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Source indication
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: Information about the source of the object.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Status
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The condition of an object at a given instant in time.
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: NOTE: IALA added listed values. The codes will have to verified when submitting the new listed values to the GI registry.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: permanent
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: intended to last or function indefinitely.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: occasional
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: acting on special occasions happening irregularly.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: recommended
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: presented as worthy of confidence, acceptance, use, etc.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: not in use
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: no longer used for the purpose intended disused.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: periodic/intermittent
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: recurring at intervals.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: reserved
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: set apart for some specific use.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: temporary
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: meant to last only for a time.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: private
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: not in public ownership or operation.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mandatory
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: compulsory enforced.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: extinguished
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: no longer lit

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: illuminated
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: lit by floodlights, strip lights, etc.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: historic
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: famous in history of historical interest.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: public
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: belonging to, available to, used or shared by, the community as a whole and not restricted to private use.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: synchronized
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: occur at a time, coincide in point of time, be contemporary or simultaneous.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: watched
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: looked at or observed over a period of time especially so as to be aware of any movement or change.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: un-watched
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: usually automatic in operation, without any permanently-stationed personnel to superintend it.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: existence doubtful
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an object that has been reported but has not been definitely determined to exist.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: confirmed
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: made certain as to truth, accuracy, validity, availability, etc.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: candidate
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: Item selected for an action

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: under modification
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: Item that is in the process of being modified

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: candidate for modification
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: Item selected for modification

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: under removal/deletion
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: Item in the process of being removed or deleted

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: removed/deleted
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: Item that has been removed or deleted

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Technique of sounding measurement
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: Survey method used to obtain depth information

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: found by echo-sounder
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was determined by using an instrument that determines depth of water by measuring the time interval between emission of a sonic or ultrasonic signal and return of its echo from the bottom.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: found by side-scan-sonar
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was computed from a record produced by active sonar in which fixed acoustic beams are directed into the water perpendicularly to the direction of travel to scan the bottom and generate a record of the bottom configuration.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: found by multi-beam
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was determined by using a wide swath echo sounder that uses multiple beams to measure depths directly below and transverse to the ship's track.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: found by diver
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was determined by a person skilled in the practice of diving.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: found by lead-line
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was determined by using a line, graduated with attached marks and fastened to a sounding lead.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: swept by wire-drag
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the given area was determined to be free from navigational dangers to a certain depth by towing a buoyed wire at the desired depth by two launches, or a least depth was identified using the same technique.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: found by laser
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was determined by using an instrument that measures distance by emitting timed pulses of laser light and measuring the time between emission and reception of the reflected pulses.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: swept by vertical acoustic system
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the given area has been swept using a system comprised of multiple echo sounder transducers attached to booms deployed from the survey vessel.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: found by electromagnetic sensor
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was determined by using an instrument that compares electromagnetic signals.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: photogrammetry
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was determined by applying mathematical techniques to photographs.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: satellite imagery
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was determined by using instruments placed aboard an artificial satellite.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: found by levelling
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the depth was determined by using levelling techniques to find the elevation of the point relative to a datum.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: swept by side-scan-sonar
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the given area was determined to be free from navigational dangers to a certain depth by towing a side-scan-sonar.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: computer generated
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the sounding was determined from a bottom model constructed using a computer.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Textual description
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: the string encodes the file name of an external text file that contains the text in English.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Textual description in national language
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The file name of an external text file that contains the text in a national language.
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: The attribute 'textual description in national language' indicates whether a text file containing text extracted from relevant pilot books or navigational publications is available.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Topmark/daymark shape
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The shape a topmark or day mark exhibits
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: NOTE: IALA added enumerates, codes must be verified after approval for registry.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: cone, point up
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: is where the vertex points up. A cone is a solid figure generated by straight lines drawn from a fixed point (the vertex) to a circle in a plane not containing the vertex. Cones are commonly used as International Association of Lighthouse Authorities - IALA topmarks lateral.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: cone, point down
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: is where the vertex points down. A cone is a solid figure generated by straight lines drawn from a fixed point (the vertex) to a circle in a plane not containing the vertex. Cones are commonly used as International Association of Lighthouse Authorities - IALA topmarks lateral.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: sphere
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a body the surface of which is at all points equidistant from the centre. Spheres are commonly used as International Association of Lighthouse Authorities - IALA topmarks safe water.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: 2 spheres
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: two black spheres are commonly used as an International Association of Lighthouse Authorities - IALA topmark (isolated danger).

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: cylinder (can)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a solid geometrical figure generated by straight lines fixed in direction and describing with one of point a closed curve, especially a circle (in which case the figure is circular cylinder, it's ends being parallel circles). Cylinders are commonly used as International Association of Lighthouse Authorities - IALA topmarks lateral.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: board
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: usually of rectangular shape, made from timber or metal and used to provide a contrast with the natural background of a daymark. The actual daymark is often painted on to this board.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: x-shape (St. Andrew's cross)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: having a shape or a cross-section like the capital letter X. An x-shape as an International Association of Lighthouse Authorities - IALA topmark should be 3 dimensional in shape. It is made of at least three crossed bars.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: upright cross (St. George's Cross)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a cross with one vertical member and one horizontal member, i.e. similar in shape to the character '+'.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: cube, point up
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a cube standing on one of its vertexes. A cube is a solid contained by six equal squares a regular hexahedron (The New Shorter Oxford English Dictionary. 1993. vol 2)

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: 2 cones, point to point
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: 2 cones, one above the other, with their vertices together in the centre.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: 2 cones, base to base
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: 2 cones, one above the other, with their bases together in the centre and their vertices pointing up and down.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: rhombus
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a plane figure having four equal sides and equal opposite angles (two acute and two obtuse) an oblique equilateral parallelogram.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: 2 cones (points upward)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: 2 cones, one above the other, with their vertices pointing up.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: 2 cones (points downward)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: 2 cones, one above the other, with their vertices pointing down.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: besom, point up (broom or perch)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: besom: a bundle of rods or twigs. perch: a staff placed on top of a buoy, rock or shoal as a mark for navigation.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: besom, point down (broom or perch)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: besom: a bundle of rods or twigs. perch: a staff placed on top of a buoy, rock or shoal as a mark for navigation.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: flag
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a flag mounted on a short pole.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: sphere over rhombus
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: A sphere located above a rhombus.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: square
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a plane figure with four right angles and four equal straight sides

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: rectangle, horizontal
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a rectangle is a plane figure with four right angles and four straight sides, opposite sides being parallel and equal in length . A horizontal rectangle is where the two longer opposite sides are standing horizontally.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: rectangle, vertical
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a rectangle is a plane figure with four right angles and four straight sides, opposite sides being parallel and equal in length. A vertical rectangle is where the two longer opposite sides are standing vertically.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: trapezium, up
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: which stands on its longer parallel side. A trapezium is a quadrilateral having one pair of opposite sides parallel.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: trapezium, down
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: which stands on its shorter parallel side. A trapezium is a quadrilateral having one pair of opposite sides parallel.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: triangle, point up
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: A triangle, point up. A triangle is a figure having three angles and three sides.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: triangle, point down
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: A triangle, point down. A triangle is a figure having three angles and three sides.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: circle
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a perfectly round plane figure whose circumference is everywhere equidistant from its centre.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: two upright crosses (one over the other)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: two upright crosses, generally vertically disposed one above the other.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: T-shape
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: having a shape like the capital letter T.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: triangle pointing up over a circle
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a triangle, vertex uppermost, located above a circle.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: upright cross over a circle
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an upright cross located above a circle.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: rhombus over a circle
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a rhombus located above a circle.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: circle over a triangle pointing up
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: a circle located over a triangle, vertex uppermost.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: other shape (see INFORM)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:remarks: (Not defined in the GI Registry as of Dec. 2016)

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: tubular
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: Having the form of or consisting of a tube.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Traffic flow
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: The direction of travel

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: inbound
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: traffic flow in a general direction toward a port or similar destination.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: outbound
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: traffic flow in a general direction away from a port or similar point of origin.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: one-way
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: traffic flow in one general direction only.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: two-way
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: traffic flow in two generally opposite directions.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Type of battery
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: Types of storage battery used to power equipment such as lights

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Type of buoy
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: Type equipment used as a buoy in a particular installation

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Type of environment observation equipment
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: Type of sensor used to observe the environment. e.g. Anemometer, fog monitor, etc.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Type of light
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: Type of light equipment

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Value of geographical range
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The greatest distance at which a light can be seen as a function of the curvature of the earth and the heights of the light source and the observer.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Value of luminous range
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The greatest distance at which a light can be seen merely as a function of its luminous intensity, the meteorological visibility, and the sensitivity of the observer's eye.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Value of maximum range
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The extreme distance at which an object can be seen or a signal detected.
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: This attribute does not apply to lights where the attribute 'value of nominal range' should be used.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Value of nominal range
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The nominal range at which an object can be seen or a signal detected.
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: The nominal range is normally the luminous range of a light in a homogeneous atmosphere in which the meteorological visibility is 10 sea miles (IHO Hydrographic Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 4218).

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Vertical datum
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: Vertical datum used for measuring elevations of points on the earth's surface. Its the datum to which both heights and soundings are referred.
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: When the vertical datum is unknown, such as water areas above locks, the value 'local datum' is to be used, and further details may be encoded using 'INFORM'. The +0.3m approximation quoted in the 'approximate' levels is somehow arbitrary and follows the British example of their definition for 'approximate LAT'.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mean low water springs
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (MLWS) - the average height of the low waters of spring tides.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mean lower low water springs
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (MLLWS) - the average height of lower low water springs at a place.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mean sea level
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (MSL) - the average height of the surface of the sea at a tide station for all stages of the tide over a 19-year period, usually determined from hourly height readings measured from a fixed predetermined reference level.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: lowest low water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level conforming to the lowest tide observed at a place, or some what lower.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mean low water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (MLW) - the average height of all low waters at a place over a 19-year period.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: lowest low water springs
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level conforming to the lowest water level observed at a place at spring tides during a period of time shorter than 19 years.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: approximate mean low water springs
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level, usually within ' 0.3m from that of mean low water springs (MLWS).

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: Indian spring low water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (ISLW) - an arbitrary tidal datum approximating the level of the mean of the lower low water at spring tides.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: low water springs
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level, approximating that of mean low water springs (MLWS).

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: approximate lowest astronomical tide
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level, usually within ' 0.3m from that of lowest astronomical tide (LAT).

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: nearly lowest low water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level approximating the lowest water level observed at a place, usually equivalent to the Indian spring low water (ISLW).

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mean lower low water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (MLLW) - the average height of the lower low waters at a place over a 19-year period.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: low water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an approximation of mean low water adopted as the reference level for a limited area, irrespective of better determinations at a later date.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: approximate mean low water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level, usually within ' 0.3m from that of mean low water (MLW).

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: approximate mean lower low water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level, usually within ' 0.3m from that of mean lower low water (MLLW).

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mean high water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (MHW) - the average height of all high waters at a place over a 19-year period.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mean high water springs
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (MHWS) - the average height of the high waters of spring tides.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: high water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the highest level reached at a place by the water surface in one tidal cycle.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: approximate mean sea level
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level, usually within ' 0.3m from that of mean sea level (MSL).

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: high water springs
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level, approximating that of mean high water springs (MHWS).

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mean higher high water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (MHHW) - the average height of higher high waters at a place over a 19-year period.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: equinoctial spring low water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the level of low water springs near the time of an equinox.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: lowest astronomical tide
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (LAT) - the lowest tide level which can be predicted to occur under average meterological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: local datum
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary datum defined by a local harbour authority, from which levels and tidal heights are measured by this authority.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: international great lakes datum 1985
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (IGLD 1985) - a vertical reference system with its zero based on the mean water level at Rimouski/Pointe-au-P??re, Quebec, over the period 1970 to 1988.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: mean water level
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the average of all hourly water levels over the available period of record.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: lower low water large tide
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (LLWLT) - the average of the lowest low waters, one from each of 19 years of observations.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: higher high water large tide
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: (HHWLT) - the average of the highest high waters, one from each of 19 years of observations.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: nearly highest high water
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an arbitrary level approximating the highest water level observed at a place, usually equivalent to the high water springs.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: highest astronomical tide (HAT)
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: the highest tidal level which can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and under any combination of astronomical conditions.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Vertical length
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The total vertical length of an object.
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: For floating objects: the vertical distance from the surface of water to the highest point of that object. For fixed objects: the vertical distance from seabed or ground to the highest point of that object. For objects on top of other objects: the vertical distance from the lowest to the highest point of that object. Vertical length measurements do not require a datum. The unit of measure is defined in the HUNI subfield of the DSPM record or in the HUNITS attribute of the M_UNIT meta object class, e.g., metre (m). The resolution is 0.1 m or 0.1 ft.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Vertical uncertainty
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: The best estimate of the vertical accuracy of heights, vertical distances and vertical clearances, excluding sounding measurements. The one-dimensional error. The error is assumed to be positive and negative. The plus/minus character shall not be encoded.
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:remarks: The unit of measure is defined in the HUNI subfield of the DSPM record or in the HUNITS attribute of the M_UNIT meta object class, e.g., metre (m). The resolution is 0.1 m or 0.1 ft.

S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:name: Visually conspicuous
S100FC:S100_FC_SimpleAttribute.S100FC:definition: Relating to a features ability to be clearly seen and identified

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: visually conspicuous
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: term applied to an object either natural or artificial which is distinctly and notably visible from seaward.

S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:label: not visually conspicuous
S100FC:listedValue.S100FC:definition: an object which is visible from seaward, but is not conspicuous.

S100FC:S100_FC_ComplexAttribute.S100FC:name: Contact address
S100FC:S100_FC_ComplexAttribute.S100FC:definition: Direction or superscription of a letter, package, etc., specifying the name of the place to which it is directed, and optionally a contact person or organisation who should receive it. (Oxford English Dictionary, 2nd Ed., adapted).

S100FC:S100_FC_ComplexAttribute.S100FC:name: Survey date range
S100FC:S100_FC_ComplexAttribute.S100FC:definition: The complex attribute describes the period of the hydrographic survey, as the time between its sub-attributes.

S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:name: Peer
S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:definition: The role given to an object of equal status in the relationship.

S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:name: parent
S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:definition: The role given to the main object in a relationship

S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:name: Child
S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:definition: The role given to the subordinate object(s) in a relationship

S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:name: Navigable track
S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:definition: The role given to the navigable part of the navigation line

S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:name: Navigation line
S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:definition: The role given to the navigation line(s) that is generally formed between two or more objects, or by one object and a bearing

S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:name: Spatial Quality
S100FC:S100_FC_Role.S100FC:definition: special role for the GML format to use in quality associations for spatial objects

S100FC:S100_FC_InformationAssociation.S100FC:name: Spatial Quality
S100FC:S100_FC_InformationAssociation.S100FC:definition: an information association for the binding between a spatial object and the Spatial Uncertainty information type.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureAssociation.S100FC:name: RangeSystem
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureAssociation.S100FC:definition: An association between a navigational line and the part of that line that is safe to navigate along

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureAssociation.S100FC:name: Aggregations
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureAssociation.S100FC:definition: Aggregation of two or more objects

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureAssociation.S100FC:name: Associations
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureAssociation.S100FC:definition: Association between two or more objects

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureAssociation.S100FC:name: Structure/Equipment
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureAssociation.S100FC:definition: An aggregation between a structure object and the equipment that is mounted on it.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Beacon, special purpose/general
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A special purpose beacon is primarily used to indicate an area or feature, the nature of which is apparent from reference to a chart, Sailing Directions or Notices to Mariners (UKHO NP 735, 5th Edition). Beacon in general: A beacon whose appearance or purpose is not adequately known.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A beacon is a prominent specially constructed object forming a conspicuous mark as a fixed aid to navigation or for use in hydrographic survey (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 420). Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Beacon, lateral
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A lateral beacon is used to indicate the port or starboard hand side of the route to be followed. They are generally used for well defined channels and are used in conjunction with a conventional direction of buoyage.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A beacon is a prominent specially constructed object forming a conspicuous mark as a fixed aid to navigation or for use in hydrographic survey (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 420). Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Beacon, cardinal
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A cardinal beacon is used in conjunction with the compass to indicate where the mariner may find the best navigable water. It is placed in one of the four quadrants (North, East, South and West), bounded by inter-cardinal bearings from the point marked.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A beacon is a prominent specially constructed object forming a conspicuous mark as a fixed aid to navigation or for use in hydrographic survey (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 420). Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Beacon, isolated danger
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: An isolated danger beacon is a beacon erected on an isolated danger of limited extent, which has navigable water all around it.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A beacon is a prominent specially constructed object forming a conspicuous mark as a fixed aid to navigation or for use in hydrographic survey (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 420). Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Beacon, safe water
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A safe water beacon is a prominent specially constructed object forming a conspicuous mark as a fixed aid to navigation or for use in hydrographic survey.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A safe water beacon may be used to indicate that there is navigable water around the mark. (UKHO NP 735, 5th Edition) Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Buoy, installation
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: An installation buoy is a buoy used for loading tankers with gas or oil.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A buoy is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 565).

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Buoy, lateral
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A lateral buoy is used to indicate the port or starboard hand side of the route to be followed. They are generally used for well defined channels and are used in conjunction with a conventional direction of buoyage.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Buoy, cardinal
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A cardinal buoy is used in conjunction with the compass to indicate where the mariner may find the best navigable water. It is placed in one of the four quadrants (North, East, South and West), bounded by inter-cardinal bearings from the point marked.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A buoy is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary S-32 5th Edition, 565). Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Buoy, safe water
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A safe water buoy is used to indicate that there is navigable water around the mark.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A buoy is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 565). Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Buoy, isolated danger
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A isolated danger buoy is a buoy moored on or above an isolated danger of limited extent, which has navigable water all around it.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A buoy is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 565). Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Buoy, special purpose/general
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A special purpose buoy is primarily used to indicate an area or feature, the nature of which is apparent from reference to a chart, Sailing Directions or Notices to Mariners (UKHO NP 735, 5th Edition). Buoy in general: A buoy whose appearance or purpose is not adequately known.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A buoy is a floating object moored to the bottom in a particular place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes. (IHO Dictionary, S-32, 5th Edition, 565). Topmark, light, fog signal, radar reflector and retro-reflector are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Offshore platform
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A permanent offshore structure, either fixed or floating, used in the production of oil or natural gas.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Light vessel
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A distinctively marked vessel anchored or moored at a charted point, to serve as an aid to navigation. By night, it displays a characteristic light(s) and is usually equipped with other devices, such as fog signal, submarine sound signal, and radio-beacon, to assist navigation.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: Also called 'light ship'. The light(s), fog signal etc. of a light vessel is a separate object, handled as with buoys, beacons, etc.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Pile
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A long heavy timber or section of steel, wood, concrete, etc. forced into the earth which may serve as a support, as for a pier, or a free standing pole within a marine environment.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Silo/tank
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: An enclosed container, used for storage.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Landmark
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A prominent object at a fixed location which can be used in determining a location or a direction.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Light float
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A boat-like structure used instead of a light buoy in waters where strong streams or currents are experienced, or when a greater elevation than that of a light buoy is necessary.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: The light of a light float is a separate object, handled as with buoys, beacons, etc.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Lighthouse
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A distinctive structure on or off a coast exhibiting a major light designed to serve as an aid to navigation. (IHO S-32 - 2822, 5th Edition, 1994).

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Topmark
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A characteristic shape secured at the top of a buoy or beacon to aid in its identification.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: The body carrying the topmark is a separate object.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Light
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A luminous or lighted aid to navigation.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A light may be fixed on a buoy, beacon, tower, etc. These are separate objects.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Fog signal
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A warning signal transmitted by a vessel, or aid to navigation, during periods of low visibility. Also, the device producing such a signal.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Retro-reflector
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A means of distinguishing unlighted marks at night. Retro-reflective material is secured to the mark in a particular pattern to reflect back light.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: The body carrying the retro-reflector is a separate object.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Radar reflector
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A device capable of, or intended for, reflecting radar signals.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: A radar reflector is usually a tetrahedron or pentagonal corner reflector to facilitate reflection towards the sender.(International Maritime Dictionary, 2nd Ed.). The object 'radar reflector' is only used to encode a device specifically intended to reflect radar signals. If any other object, e.g. topmark, buoy, beacon, etc. is radar conspicuous, because of its construction, the attribute 'CONRAD' must be used.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Environment Observation Equipment
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A sensor used to observe the environment.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Daymark
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: The identifying characteristics of an aid to navigation which serve to facilitate its recognition against a daylight viewing background.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: On those structures that do not by themselves present an adequate viewing area to be seen at the required distance, the aid is made more visible by affixing a daymark to the structure. A daymark so affixed has a distinctive colour and shape depending on the purpose of the aid.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Radar transponder beacon
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A transponder beacon transmitting a coded signal on radar frequency, permitting an interrogating craft to determine the bearing and range of the transponder.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: The object class 'radar transponder beacon' is only used to encode the technical equipment independent of the structure on which it is located (e.g. a beacon, light-vessel or tower).

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Recommended track
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A track recommended to all or only certain vessels.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: Recommended tracks include all channels recommended for hydrographic reasons to lead safely between shoal depths. The use of such tracks is generally left to the discretion of the mariner and will depend on the vessel's draught, the state of the tide, adequacy of navigational aids and so on (IHO Chart Specifications, M-4). The recommended track is that portion of a 'navigation line' that a ship should use for navigation. In the case of a two-way recommended track only one value of orientation is encoded (in the attribute ORIENT); the other value can be deduced (i.e. the value in ORIENT + 180 degrees).

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Navigation line
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A navigation line is a straight line extending towards an area of navigational interest and generally generated by two navigational aids or one navigational aid and a bearing.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: The extent of the navigation line depends on the visibility of the navigational aid(s). The attribute 'orientation' (ORIENT) specifies the orientation of the navigation line measured from the water towards the navigational aid(s). The recommended track is that portion of a 'navigation line' that a ship should use for navigation.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Aggregation
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: Used to identify an aggregation of two or more objects. This aggregation may be named.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: An aggregation could be used to combine objects that are related in some way (is-a-part-of, is-a-component-of) into a higher level object. For example: an aggregation relationship may be used to form a traffic separation scheme from traffic separation lane parts, boundaries, etc.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Association
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: Used to identify an association between two or more objects. The association may be named.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: For example, an association relationship may be used to indicate that a buoy marks a wreck.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Data coverage
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A geographical area that describes the coverage and extent of spatial types.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: Manually added, and types of attribute max and min display scale changed to integer in accordance with latest guidance.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Local Direction of Buoyage
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: An area within which the navigational system of marks has been established in relation to a specific direction.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Navigational system of marks
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: An area within which a specific system of navigational marks applies and/or a common direction of buoyage.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Quality of NonBathymetric Data
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: An area within which a uniform assessment of the quality of the non-bathymetric data exists

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Sounding datum
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: An area of uniform sounding datum.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Vertical datum of data
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: Any level surface from which to reference elevations. Also called datum level, reference level, reference plane, levelling datum, datum for heights.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Aids To Navigation
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A visual, acoustical, or radio device, external to a ship, designed to assist in determining a safe course or a vessel's position, or to warn of dangers and/or obstructions. Aids to navigation usually include buoys, beacons, fog signals, lights, radio beacons, leading marks, radio position fixing systems and GNSS which are chart-related and assist safe navigation.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: Abstract features are defined only in skeletal form in the catalogue, i.e., without attribute bindings. They are used to reduce the need to specify associations in their sub-types, since the number of such 'inline' association specifications is quite large for the Structure/Equipment associations. The attributes are defined within the non-abstract sub-types.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Equipment
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: The implements used in an operation or activity.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: Abstract features are defined only in skeletal form in the catalogue, i.e., without attribute bindings. They are used to reduce the need to specify associations in their sub-types, since the number of such 'inline' association specifications is quite large for the Structure/Equipment associations. The attributes are defined within the non-abstract sub-types.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Structure Object
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: Something (such as a house, tower, bridge, etc.) that is built by putting parts together and that usually stands on its own.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: Abstract features are defined only in skeletal form in the catalogue, i.e., without attribute bindings. They are used to reduce the need to specify associations in their sub-types, since the number of such 'inline' association specifications is quite large for the Structure/Equipment associations. The attributes are defined within the non-abstract sub-types.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Generic Beacon
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A fixed artificial navigation mark that can be recognised by its shape, colour, pattern, topmark or light character, or a combination of these. It may carry various additional aids to navigation.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: Abstract features are defined only in skeletal form in the catalogue, i.e., without attribute bindings. They are used to reduce the need to specify associations in their sub-types, since the number of such 'inline' association specifications is quite large for the Structure/Equipment associations. The attributes are defined within the non-abstract sub-types.

S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:name: Generic Buoy
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:definition: A floating object moored to the bottom in a particular (charted) place, as an aid to navigation or for other specific purposes.
S100FC:S100_FC_FeatureType.S100FC:remarks: Abstract features are defined only in skeletal form in the catalogue, i.e., without attribute bindings. They are used to reduce the need to specify associations in their sub-types, since the number of such 'inline' association specifications is quite large for the Structure/Equipment associations. The attributes are defined within the non-abstract sub-types.
